benchmark_details.name: Commonsense Frame Completion (CFC)
benchmark_details.overview: Commonsense Frame Completion (CFC) is a novel generative task that evaluates common sense via multiple open-ended generations, capturing the probabilistic nature of common sense by allowing for multiple correct answers to questions.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate implicit common sense in various contexts through a generative question answering task with multiple correct answers.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The collected answers may be biased towards English speakers in the US, and the framework may not capture commonsense across diverse cultures.

data.source: CommonGen dataset, which provides sentences with implicit commonsense knowledge.
data.size: 63,788 context sentences, resulting in 228,170 pairs of context questions with missing slots.
data.annotation: Collected via human annotators on platforms like Amazon MTurk.

methodology.calculation: The common sense evaluation is calculated by deriving a categorical distribution over answer clusters and measuring KL divergence between the ground truth and the model-generated answers.
methodology.interpretation: A lower KL divergence indicates a better performance of the model in capturing the common sense knowledge distribution.
methodology.validation: Verified through correlations of PROBEVAL with human judgments.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset may not adequately represent diverse global populations due to its focus on English speakers in the US.
